But if the reccurrency does cause a large hit in fitness, this would
be removed from the specie/population by the normal means of evolution.  

I agree, there is no correct way, to firing order but regardless of
which scheme you use, evolution should(may, perhaps etc) come up with
a topology that provides the best answer for the chosen scheme.

Just MHO.

Cheers

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@g...> wrote:
> > Actually, I originally had NEAT written to work John's way but Risto
> > (my advisor) told me that no one activates a network like that; he
> > said, "why would you do it that way?"  At the time I just thought
> > I'd made a mistake so I switched to the "standard" method, but now
> > as I think about it again, it's worth a second look.
> 
> On the subject of single-pass activation, there is a potential gotcha...
> 
> As long as the network is not recurrent, you're fine.  As soon as it
> becomes recurrent, you have to make a decision about how to order the
> firing, because there is no 'correct' way.  Here's the gotcha:  When
> you add topology to an existing network, it may cause you to make a
> different choice of what order to activate it.  Topology and weights
> that may have been tuned to a particular firing order may suddenly get
> fired in a different order, which may cause it to take a huge hit in
> fitness.  For a discriminator network, that shouldn't ever be a
> problem.  For a controller, it may very well present a problem to the
> evolution of the network.
> 
> The solution, of course, is to have a deterministic approach to
> determining firing order that will NOT have any possibility of the
> addition of new topology changing the firing order of any of the old
> topology that is not connected to that new topology.  When you have a
> loop, and you need to determine which path to activate first, you have
> some choices to make:
> 
> 1. You can't choose randomly, because that's not deterministic
> 2. You could choose to activate the longest path first, but then you
> run the risk of new topology changing the firing order
> 3. Or the best option:  Choose based on AGE of the topology.  
> 
> With option 3, you get a deterministic method of determining firing
> order that will not be suceptable to the problems that the evolution
> of new topology might cause.
> 
> However, that said, it is entirely possible that having such a firing
> pattern might make a controller network harder to evolve, as you might
> potentially lose the ability to have a 'time delay' circuit.
> 
> If I were you, I would retain the ability to fire the networks using
> either method.  Choose the firing-order optimizer for classifier
> networks, to speed up your evolution, and use the real-time firing
> method for controllers that need to have time-based processing.
> 
> -- John
